title: Is Bank of America the one that is going to sue me or the creditor
question: I just got word that bank of america is going to sue me and they are currently trying to serve me. The DF group is the one telling me I could settle or that they could end up garnishing my wages but My husband is unemployed we have a daughter and I am currently pregnant. Would the judge take that into consideration or should I try and file for bankruptcy.
answers:
You should first see if you can settle the lawsuit, once you are served. If the process server is uanble to hand it to you personally, they are permitted by law to hand it to anyone at your home who is an adult or they can go to your workplace and hand it to a supervisor or person who appears in charge of the workplace. Evading the process server really does not help you and a judge that learns about this could also simply have the lawsuit published as the form of service.

On my Avvo profile I have several legal guides, including one on settling a debt collection lawsuit. You should review the tips on my legal guide and then see if you can settle, if they are willing to be reasonable. If they are not willing to work with you within your tight budget, then your choices are to defend the lawsuit (with your debt collection defense lawyer), let it become a default judgment which will keep you from adding to the costs of the litigation and may reduce the accrued interest, or file bankruptcy.

The bankruptcy option is a last resort, if you have many other debts that you need to discharge right now. I do not know the DF Group, but if they are not lawyers, then they cannot assist you with the litigation, and you should be warned that such company may console you to not worry about it, but then you learn that the debt collection attorney filed a default judgment against you. I have had many clients who have an experience with debt negotiators, who don't know what to do with a lawsuit and give bad advice.

My web site, linked below, also walks you through your options regarding a credit card lawsuit. Even if a judgment is entered against you, that does not mean that your will be wages garnished, because you can file with the levying officer a claim of exemption, which would then allow you to present your financial circumstances to a judge, who may then decide to exempt you from the wage garnishment, because of your need to pay your family's necessary living expenses.

Be very careful negotiating with collection agencies. The first thing to do is to determine if you actually owe the debt. Many people are getting harassed for debts that they do not even owe! Next determine if the statute of limitation for collection of the debt has run. While it would be nice to wrap this up without an attorney, I have seen creditors make deals for partial payments, as payment in full, who then sue you for the difference anyway. There are laws to prevent it, but consumers are legally unsophisticated and they get run over by creditors all the time. See an attorney. If your debt out weighs your income, bankruptcy is a viable solution and a BK attorney (a good one) can help you decide if this is the right solution for you.

Best of luck to you.

You should try to explore and exhaust all options before doing anything of haste in regards to bankruptcy but also keep in mind you have thirty days to respond to a complaint of the date you are properly served. A judge could consider a situation as yourself but in the end a judge has to follow the law. So before all that happens you could contact opposing counsel to see what they are asking for and they may settle. If you can't seem to negotiate then you may consider in hiring an attorney.

Best of luck!

If you are referring to a credit card purchase for which the issuing bank already paid the vendor, I would think that the lawsuit would be brought by the bank.

As for your question about whether the judge will take into consideration your financial and family circumstances, I don't see any issue as to judicial discretion here. The judge will be asked, after a trial, to enter judgment.

Your best bet might be to contact plaintiff's attorney, explain the circumstances, and explore whether the matter can be settled -- either through an installment agreement, a diminished payment, or a combination of both.

Please note that I am a New York attorney and cannot advise you as to the application of California state law. For that reason, you may wish to consult a local attorney.

Good luck to you.
